I'll send you a private message tomorrow with her contact info. Hang in there! These situations are scary for sure, but they get less so as we find out more information and are able to take action.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, looking for surgeon in Northern NJ or NYC wenben bridgegal25

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2015 02:28PM - edited Mar 15, 2015 02:32PM by Larkspur Alicki, sorry, I didn't see your question till just now. In my case, it was the MRI that revealed the tiny mass of invasive cancer (4 mm). My breast surgeon agreed with me that I should have annual MRIs along with mammograms, as each can detect problems that the other can't. Currently, I'm waiting for the results of the Oncotype test to see if chemo is in my future. If not, then I'll start radiation. The RO I saw thinks that chemo is unlikely, but I think we've all learned that there are no sure things in this experience.
Posts.Title: What is an MRI guided biopsy like? iwannabefree50 pennsygal

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 06:35AM Larkspur wrote: I had my first breast MRI earlier this week in advance of DCIS surgery on my right boob next Wednesday, and I can confirm what others have said here: being on your stomach is easier than on your back if you're claustrophobic, as I am. I took a precautionary Xanax about half an hour before the MRI, which definitely helped. I lay there listening to all the bangs and bongs and pretended that I was attending an experimental music concert while mildly stoned. I also had a "panic button" to squeeze if necessary; I found I didn't need it, but as Janett noted, having that option was reassuring. The tech staff was very kind and helpful, asking me at intervals how I was doing. It was an unpleasant surprise to hear from my surgeon yesterday, saying that the MRI had turned up "some things" on both breasts that hadn't shown up in any recent mammograms, and that she wants to do MRI-guided biopsies on them on Monday. So back into the doughnut I go. "We'll give you an Ativan!" and "There's no need to panic," she told me brightly, which of course triggers instant panic!--just as telling angry people to "calm down" only inflames them further. I'm reminding myself that the medical team is probably just trying to cover all bases, that it's good to have this technology that can catch things so early, and so on, but it was just one more piece of recent unwelcome medical news to deal with. I know that everyone here can relate!
Posts.Title: Please describe your breast MRI CeciliaVera Trvler

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2015 07:40AM Larkspur wrote: Florida, my lumpectomy was three weeks ago at Lenox Hill Hosp.; this coming Monday, I'll meet with a radiation onc. also at LHH to set up that process. And I've seen a medical onc.who ordered the Oncotype Dx test to see if I would benefit from chemo also; I too am hoping that just radiation--and hormonal therapy--will suffice. Fingers crossed for both of us!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, looking for surgeon in Northern NJ or NYC wenben bridgegal25

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2015 01:34PM Larkspur wrote: IWanna, this procedure's much less painful and upsetting than you might think. As with the MRI and the stereotactic core biopsy (SCB), you're lying face-down; you have local anesthetic, and they give you a relaxant beforehand--Ativan, in my case. ( I actually had both breasts biopsied at the same time, with a doctor working away on either side--probably the closest I'll ever come to a three-way.) They send you home with a cold-pack and suggest that you wear a sports bra, as they did for the SCB. Tylenol took care of any pain in my case, but if you had significant pain after your SCB, let the team know and maybe they can give you a prescription for something stronger. Really not a big deal; and in my case, it may literally have been a life-saver. My annual mammogram and the follow-up mammos and SCB revealed the presence of DCIS, but the pre-surgery MRI showed a couple of other suspicious areas, and the MRI-guided biopsy confirmed some invasive ductal cancer that the mammograms didn't catch. Luckily for me, it was small and slow-growing, and there's no lymph node involvement. Without the MRI & the guided biopsy, my story might be very different.
Posts.Title: What is an MRI guided biopsy like? iwannabefree50 pennsygal

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2015 05:04PM Larkspur wrote: Sspc, they did leave a marker in my breast (removed six weeks later during the subsequent lumpectomy), and there was a tiny scar. Please don't worry about the procedure! The worst part of it is having to lie very still, face down, for a period of time--tough on the neck. I went directly to my job after mine, with no significant pain. I'm sure you'll handle it well.
Posts.Title: What is an MRI guided biopsy like? iwannabefree50 pennsygal

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2015 11:33AM Larkspur wrote: Jenga, I've found that my job is a welcome distraction from "real life." A few years ago, it helped me get through a period of deep grief after the death of a sibling, and it's helped me more recently as I've waited to hear the findings of several biopsies and a lumpectomy. Having a workplace to go to, colleagues to interact with, and tasks to focus on all took my mind off of a scary situation and made the waiting seem to go a little faster. If you basically like your job and you feel physically up to it after your surgery, my recommendation is to go back to it!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy + radiation- going back to work in between? Jenga60 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2018 08:17AM Larkspur wrote: Chasityanne, very sorry for what you're going through, but it's good that you've found this invaluable site, which has helped so many of us through scary times. Others will be along to offer empathy, reassurance, and factual information, so I'll just limit myself to a couple of things. Here's the link to a document on this site to interpreting our pathology reports: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/pat... "Triple-positive" means that your cancer tested positive for the hormones estrogen and progesterone, and the gene HER2: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/her... The meds you mention above have good success rates in treating your type of breast cancer. The worst and most frightening time in this process is where you are right now, with so many unknowns. But you have a treatment plan in place, so the way forward will soon become more clear. Spend a little time exploring this site, especially the community forums for Stage IV and HER2+ breast cancer, and you'll find a wealth of information and support. Hang in there, and please keep us posted on your situation.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed yesterday. chasityanne Groovywilma

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2017 10:06AM Larkspur wrote: CMary, I also worked all during rads with no problems. (Well, I did fall asleep during one afternoon meeting, but that might have happened anyway.) I found it was helpful emotionally to keep my life as normal as possible all through treatment, and since you love your job, you may feel the same. You mention that it's a high-energy one, and that energy may carry you smoothly along, but if you are noticing fatigue toward the end, you might consider exploring the half-day option that Cpeachymom suggests.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2017 03:33PM Larkspur wrote: Peaches, I've had an assortment of biopsies in recent years, and in my experience, anything below BIRADS 5 was benign. Worst case: if your upcoming biopsy is positive for cancer, they've found it at a very early point and it should be pretty easy to treat. As everyone here can confirm, you're at the hardest point in this process: waiting for appointments and for answers. Once you have the needed information, there will be a plan of action and it all gets simpler. I can imagine how scary all of this stuff is for you, especially as you recently lost a close friend to breast cancer. This is no time to play Superwoman. Ask your doc for some Xanax to help you get through this worrisome period. And good luck with the stereotactic biopsy! I've had two of them; one was fairly easy--I went on to work right after it--the other was a little more stressful, and I wish I had thought to take a Xanax before it. The surgeon who performs yours will very likely give you one, or something like it, if you ask. It's in her/his best interests to do it, as your being relaxed will make the procedure easier.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Breast Biopsy needed peaches76 Bmcocean

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2015 02:11PM Larkspur wrote: Oh, now, this phenomenon is quite interesting to me. I'm in my early 60s, well past menopause. During radiation treatment this spring, I had some intermittent minor vaginal spotting: no obvious blood, just gray-green mucous-y stuff (sorry, I know this is gross), and not much, but enough to make me uneasy, as I'd had nothing like it before. I spoke to the rad. onc. nurse about this development; she thought it was unlikely that it was connected with treatment but urged me to get it checked out with my gynecologist, which I did. I tested negative for all sorts of things, but never found out what the actual cause was. (Of course, when I went in to be examined, the problem wasn't manifesting itself.) In any case, I had a few episodes of this discharge, each lasting for a couple of days. They went away while I was still doing rads and haven't returned. I wonder if & suspect that they were rad-related, though I don't know what the cause-and-effect could be.
Posts.Title: Vaginal Bleeding during Radiation ( PLEASE HELP ) Tootiefnfruitie Larkspur

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2015 08:33PM Larkspur wrote: >The risk of having cancer develop in the other breast, especially if you had ER+/PR+ cancer is extremely low. The risk is usually stated at 0.5 - 1% per year, but a recent study found it to be even lower - at 1% at 51 months. The risk is slightly higher for ER-/PR- cancer. Kayb, can you give us a link or links to your source(s) of information? I'm not doubting you!--I'd like to read up on this topic. Thanks--

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2015 09:31AM Larkspur wrote: Pennsygal's experience sounds similar to mine. I had both boobs MRI-biopsied at the same time, with a surgeon on each side, working away--probably the closest I'll ever come to being part of a three-way. As Pennsy says, the medical professionals are right there with you, which is reassuring: you don't feel as isolated as you would during a regular MRI. If you need to sneeze or cough, they'll pause. And the Xanax will definitely help! I'm grateful that this procedure exists, as in my case, it turned up about 4 mm. of invasive cancer that the mammograms had missed. (I was originally being treated only for DCIS.) I'm very thankful that the IDC was found at a rather early stage. Chin up! Please send me a private message if you'd like any further info.
